_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This executive summary is part of the resubmission of the initial RMP plan submitted by the Amway Corporation.  Amway Corporation restructured internally in order to better manage its resources.  Amway Corporation has been renamed and divided into several business units under one parent company.  The parent company is Alticor, Inc.  Its manufacturing & distribution business unit, Access Business Group, LLC is a wholly owned subsidiary of Alticor, Inc.

Since the manufacturing plants and distribution fall under Access Business Group, LLC  this submission is now under this name.

Access Business Group, LLC has a manufacturing facility located in Ada, Michigan in with primary activities at the site include the manufacture of home and personal care products.  One process at the Site is covered by EPA¿s Risk Management Program Rule.  That process is the manufacture of aerosol products, including the storage of flammable Liquefied Petroleum Gas propellants.  Aerosol products use these propellants in their pure form or in blends made of various percentages of the base propellants based on the performance requirements of the product.  The regulated substances used in this process are Isobutane; Difluoroethane, Propane, and n-Butane.  The maximum quantities stored, are based on the quantity that could be stored in the base propellant storage tanks plus the maximum anticipated quantity that could be held in the blend storage tanks.  Maximum anticipated quantity of regulated substances on hand are; Isobutane (87,500 pounds); Difluoroethane (91,000 pounds); Propane (68,000 pounds); n-Butane (53,000 pounds).  Worst case and alternate case scenario calculations are based on a release of material from the storage tank with the largest capacity.

The propellant process is covered under OSHA¿s Process Safety Management Standard and is also regulated by EPA¿s Risk Management Program Rule, Subpart D ¿ Accidental Release Prevention Program 3.  It is Access Business Group Ada Site polic

y to comply with these regulations in order to prevent , an/or minimize, the consequences of accidental releases.

Emergency response to releases of hazardous materials is provided by the Site¿s Hazardous Materials Emergency Response Team.  The Site¿s Protection Services Department responds to fires at the incipient stage.  Additional response capability is provided by the Ada Fire Department.

The propellant process is covered under OSHA¿s Process Safety Management Standard which focuses on preventing, or minimizing, the consequences of accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  The Access Business Group Site is in compliance with the PSM Standard, protecting those in the workplace from chemical exposure, fires, and explosions.

The propellant process is also regulated by EPA¿s Risk Management Program Rule, Subpart D ¿ Accidental Release Prevention Program 3.  The Site has expanded the scope of their PSM program elements to prevent, or minimize, any off-site consequences of unwanted releases of EPA/RMP-regulated substances. 

The Access Business Group Ada Site has had no EPA/RMP reportable releases from the regulated process within, at least, the time frame in which documentation exists, which is seventeen years.

The Site has a current emergency response plan which has been coordinated with the Ada Fire Department, Kent County Local Emergency Planning Committee, and Kent County Emergency Management.  The Plan is in compliance with the National Response Team¿s Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance.  

The HazMat Team has conducted joint training and drills with the Ada Fire Department.  Public notification and alert is done in compliance with SARA Title III and Risk Management Planning requirements.  The Ada Site Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with emergency response procedures established by the Kent County Local Emergency Planning committee.

The Access Business Group Ada Site will continue to perform Process Safety Management Compliance Audits, an

d work to address any finding from these audits.  The Site will include the auditing of EPA/RMP criteria as part of subsequent PSM audits. 

Efforts will continue to perform Process Hazard Analyses, and to address any recommendations from these analyses.
